titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 680: Sermones dominicales

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 680: Sermones dominicales are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. notesStmt.note: Latin, with a poem in Middle English.
Title, attribution, and date supplied by cataloger (Zacour-Hirsch).
Incipit: Penuria studentium in materia morali paupertasque juvenum qui copia privantur librorum...
Felton's sermons exist in the following mss., Royal Ms. 8 BXII, Harleianen Mss. 537, 1327, 4238, Oxford, University College LXV, New College CCCV.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: 57 sermons for Sundays and feast days, arranged according to the liturgical calendar, with an alphabetical subject index (f. 182r-188r); Sermon, "De cruce," (f. 189r-v) in a second hand, explicit: Gregorius libro primo et quarto de pharetra, with a second table of contents (f. 190r-v). Also includes Middle English poem of 16 lines, beginning, "I ham as I ham and so will I be..." added in a later hand (f. iii recto).

supportDesc.extent: 194 leaves : 228 x 160 (154 x 100) mm. bound to 240 x 165 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, 194; [iv], [1-190]; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 36 long lines; ruled in ink; prickings visible.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a semi-cursive Gothic script in a single hand, except for f. 189r-190v in a second hand.

decoDesc.decoNote: 3-line blue initials with red penwork ornamentation and extensive rubrication throughout.
Middle English poem, f. iii recto

origin.p: Written in England, possibly Oxford, ca. 1450 (Zacour-Hirsch).

history.provenance: Formerly owned by James P. R. Lyell (bookplate, inside upper cover).
Sold by Sir William Henry Ingilby at auction at Sotheby's, 21 Oct. 1920, lot 153, to Maggs Bros.; appears in Maggs catalog 404 (1921), lot 15.
Appears in Bernard Quaritch's catalog 699 (1952), no. 61.
